p: V. jatamansi (synonymous V. wallichii DC.), popularly named as Indian valerian, is considered as an Asian counterpart for the European V. officinalis, is another important medicinal plant from the genus Valeriana, broadly recognized for its uses in anxiety, insomnia, epilepsy, and hysteria treatment (Nadkarni, 2001). Many studies are reporting the pharmacological properties of this species including the sedative, tranquilizing and neuroprotective effect, and its capacity to attenuate stress, anxiety, and depression ( Table 1) [ 67]. The anti-anxiety effect of its ethanol extract was studied on empty bottle-stimulated rats using the open field and the elevated plus-maze tests. Four bioactive compounds (hesperidin, isochlorogenic acid A, isochlorogenic acid B, and isochlorogenic acid C) were identified as the chemical markers for that effect [ 46]. There are some reports about the antidepressant effect of extracts and essential oils from this species [ 60, 68, 69, 70]. The nitric oxide pathway is involved in the antidepressant properties of essential oil from a chemotype of this species in mice [ 60]. The essential oil components inhibit nitric oxide to a critical concentration changing the vesicular release of norepinephrine and serotonin, two neurotransmitters implicated in depression.
